etymology.description: 不(bú, “not”) + 客气(“polite; to stand on ceremony”) → “don’t be so polite; you’re welcome”.
etymology.interpretation: Literally “not polite/ceremonious”; used to downplay thanks or invite others to act freely. In some contexts it can also mean “blunt” or “not courteous.”
etymology.simplification: 氣 was simplified to 气 to reduce strokes; other characters unchanged.

examples.chinese: 谢谢你(謝謝你)，不客气(不客氣)。
他夸我做得好(他誇我做得好)，我连声说不客气(我連聲說不客氣)。
examples.pinyin: Tā kuā wǒ zuò de hǎo, wǒ liánshēng shuō bú kèqi.
examples.english: He praised me for doing well, and I replied repeatedly, “You’re welcome.”

examples.chinese: 大家不客气(大家不客氣)，随便拿点心(隨便拿點心)。
examples.pinyin: Dàjiā bú kèqi, suíbiàn ná diǎnxīn.
examples.english: Everyone, don’t be shy—help yourselves to some snacks.
